BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs will become increasingly prone to triggering. Numerous dry and wet avalanches are to be expected at any time, but they can be dangerously large.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2200 m. This applies in particular towards the evening.
Avalanches can be released very easily and reach dangerously large size. Exposed buildings and exposed parts of transportation routes are endangered in isolated cases in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
Below approximately 2200 m moist and wet avalanches are possible. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
The conditions are very dangerous for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
These spring-like weather conditions will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow require caution. Especially in the regions exposed to precipitation large natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way, must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Intensive precipitation: This applies especially in the evening.
Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released naturally in all aspects. Many large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in some places endanger exposed transportation routes.
Below approximately 2200 m medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
These spring-like weather conditions will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow require caution. Especially in the regions exposed to precipitation large natural avalanches, capable of reaching a long way, must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Intensive precipitation: This applies especially in the evening.
Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow can be released naturally in all aspects. Many large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in some places endanger exposed transportation routes.
Below approximately 2200 m medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
These spring-like weather conditions will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation. Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and endanger exposed transportation routes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area heavy precipitation. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
From high-altitude starting zones in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanches can reach large size and in some places endanger transportation routes, including those situated at relatively low altitudes. This applies especially in the regions with a lot of snow.
Increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches until the temperature drops.
The conditions are critical for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall over a wide area. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions. As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days.
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
These spring-like weather conditions will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation. Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and endanger exposed transportation routes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area heavy precipitation. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
From high-altitude starting zones in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanches can reach large size and in some places endanger transportation routes, including those situated at relatively low altitudes. This applies especially in the regions with a lot of snow.
Increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches until the temperature drops.
The conditions are critical for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall over a wide area. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions. As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days.
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
These spring-like weather conditions will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wet snow require caution. Especially in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation large natural avalanches must be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last three days adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. Here they will increase in size additionally until Sunday. They can be released easily or naturally in all aspects.

During the day: Natural avalanches are further to be expected. The avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach large size in some cases. As a consequence of the precipitation moist and wet avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in some places endanger exposed transportation routes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Saturday: Above approximately 2100 m more snow fell. This applies in particular in the afternoon. Here rain fell up to 2000 m.
The southerly wind has transported the new snow significantly.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.

Sunday: Above approximately 2200 m 30 to 60 cm of snow will fall.
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Dry and moist avalanches are possible in some places.
The avalanches can reach the valleys and in some places endanger transportation routes that are exposed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the precipitation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon.
As the penetration by moisture increases more frequent wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses below approximately 2200 m.
The more recent wind slabs will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released easily and reach large size in isolated cases.
The current avalanche situation calls for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall over a wide area. The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
These spring-like weather conditions will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the precipitation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon.
As the penetration by moisture increases more frequent wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses below approximately 2200 m.
The more recent wind slabs will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released easily and reach large size in isolated cases.
The current avalanche situation calls for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall over a wide area. The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
These spring-like weather conditions will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Along the border with Switzerland above approximately 2500 m in some localities danger level 4 (high) will be reached.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last three days adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. Here they will increase in size additionally until Sunday. They can be released easily or naturally in all aspects. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is greater.

During the day: Natural avalanches are further to be expected. The avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach quite a large size. As a consequence of the precipitation moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Saturday: Above approximately 2100 m more snow fell. This applies in particular in the afternoon. Here rain fell up to 2000 m.
The southerly wind has transported the new snow significantly.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.

Sunday: Above approximately 2200 m 20 to 50 cm of snow will fall.
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Dry and moist avalanches are possible in some places.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A precarious avalanche situation will prevail. Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind, further wind slabs will form in all aspects. These can be released easily or naturally. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above the tree line, and in areas close to the tree line. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. In some cases avalanches are large.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected at any time, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on extremely steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Danger level 4 (high) will be reached. A critical avalanche situation will be encountered over a wide area. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an additional increase in the avalanche danger. 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Occasionally large natural avalanches are to be expected as the snowfall becomes more intense. Below approximately 2600 m: As the precipitation becomes more intense there will be an appreciable increase in the danger of wet and gliding avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A precarious avalanche situation will prevail. Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind, further wind slabs will form in all aspects. These can be released easily or naturally. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above the tree line, and in areas close to the tree line. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. In some cases avalanches are large.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected at any time, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on extremely steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Danger level 4 (high) will be reached. A critical avalanche situation will be encountered over a wide area. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an additional increase in the avalanche danger. 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Occasionally large natural avalanches are to be expected as the snowfall becomes more intense. Below approximately 2600 m: As the precipitation becomes more intense there will be an appreciable increase in the danger of wet and gliding avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain easily released wind slabs will form. Skiers can release avalanches very easily, including large ones. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are probable.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep slopes. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain easily released wind slabs will form. Skiers can release avalanches very easily, including large ones. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are probable.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep slopes. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, further wind slabs will form. These can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally, in particular on steep shady slopes. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2400 m. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain individual moist loose snow slides are to be expected. This applies in particular on extremely steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an additional increase in the avalanche danger. 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Natural avalanches are to be expected as the snowfall becomes more intense, especially in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. Below approximately 2600 m: As the precipitation becomes more intense there will be an appreciable increase in the danger of wet and gliding avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, further wind slabs will form. These can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally, in particular on steep shady slopes. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2400 m. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain individual moist loose snow slides are to be expected. This applies in particular on extremely steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an additional increase in the avalanche danger. 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Natural avalanches are to be expected as the snowfall becomes more intense, especially in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. Below approximately 2600 m: As the precipitation becomes more intense there will be an appreciable increase in the danger of wet and gliding avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in particular on steep shady slopes at high altitude. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. As a consequence of warming during the day more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. Mostly small moist and wet avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of the rain. This applies in particular on very steep slopes. On steep grassy slopes more medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1500 m. The wind was strong. In places that are protected from the wind wind slabs formed. The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack. The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an increase in the avalanche danger within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at intermediate and high altitudes. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
The rain will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects.
Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In the last few days wind slabs formed. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The weather conditions will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Over a wide area precipitation. The wind will be moderate to strong.
In all aspects further wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day. In addition the wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day more moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected. Small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of the rain. On very steep grassy slopes more gliding avalanches are possible. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, above approximately 2200 m. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. On steep grassy slopes more medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 2 to 25 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1800 m. The rain will give rise as the day progresses to a loss of strength within the snowpack. The wind was moderate to strong. In the vicinity of peaks wind slabs formed.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of new snow and strong wind there will be an increase in the avalanche danger within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of the precipitation medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 1700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally wet all the way through.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 1700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally wet all the way through.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1900 m. In gullies and bowls a sometimes precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. As a consequence of the solar radiation, the likelihood of wet snow slides and avalanches being released will increase. The avalanche prone locations for moist avalanches are to be found especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and on steep slopes above approximately 1900 m.
